intro: Endopogon decurrens, commonly known as the creeping sandwort, is a low-growing perennial plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of North America. It belongs to the family Montiaceae and is characterized by its prostrate growth habit and small, clustered flowers. The plant has fleshy, succulent leaves that help it retain moisture in dry environments. Its flowers are typically pale blue or violet, with five petals and stamens that are often longer than the petals. Endopogon decurrens is adapted to sandy soils and can thrive in harsh, windy conditions.
